setting: The narrator lives in a tiny village in northern New England and works in a cabin a considerable distance from his house. The family previously lived in Connecticut. The narrator's daughter, Dorothy Junior, is a college student spending a term in London. The narrator's family lives in icy New Hampshire. The narrator's mother was fourteen in Wayne, Pennsylvania, when "Gone with the Wind" came to the local theater. In 1939, in suburban Philadelphia, theaters banned "coloreds" from good seats. The narrator once worked in Greensboro, North Carolina. The narrator's younger brother visited him in Georgetown, D.C. Basketball is played in remote parts of Afghanistan. The narrator was in a Hanover, New Hampshire, bank lobby when his three-year-old daughter had a temper tantrum. The narrator is scheduled to testify before the New Hampshire legislature on broadband Internet access in rural areas, where the phone company holds a monopoly. Mount Saint Helens is located in Washington. The Indian province of Sind is mentioned. The White House is mentioned. The Roman Forum is mentioned as a location for trials. The Soviet Union and the United States are mentioned in a Cold War joke. Ohio is mentioned as where Annie grew up and Kathy lives, and the East Coast is where Annie now lives. The Midwest is mentioned in relation to weather. River City is mentioned as a setting from *The Music Man*. The narrator once returned a rental car with scrapes in Nice, France.
characters: Dorothy: The narrator's wife, who returned to full-time work a year and a half ago after the narrator quit his job. She has a fund-raising job at a law school. She is a recipient of a message stating "You win." She is skilled at "oversympathizing" to change someone's mood. She was promoted to vice president within eighteen months of resuming her career by dressing one step above her rank on casual Fridays. She puts herself on Dorothy Junior’s side regarding values but hikes because she likes it. She has a good sense of direction. She gave her son, George, his stereo. She made a pact with the narrator not to treat their kids equally, but to love them equally and deal with each situation separately. She allows Dorothy Jr. to sit with friends at a football game. She told George not to speak to his father in a certain way. She uses the backfire technique constantly, specifically oversympathizing with the narrator's mood.

George: The narrator's seventeen-year-old son, who attends a boarding school as a day student. He dislikes school food and his father's stew. He is a recipient of a message stating "You win," specifically winning an argument with his father about toothpaste. As a two-year-old, he was a devotee of "argument by the stick." His name was chosen by his father using a rhetorical trick of proposing extreme alternatives first. At age seven, he insisted on wearing shorts to school in winter and instinctively used character, logic, and emotion to win an argument with his father, specifically using a lower lip stick-out when trying not to cry. He now expresses individuality by wearing ties and pants to school. He believes that meeting a pointless challenge outweighs values like comfort and sense. He asks to sit with friends at a football game but is told no by the narrator and argues it's unfair because Dorothy Jr. was allowed. He tried the "dubitatio" technique (looking down, then staring intensely) on a girl while talking politics. He came home in a bad mood and tried to make the narrator angry by announcing the emotion in advance, but was unprepared to get mad himself. He practices bantering with the television, specifically with ads and talking heads. He learned his father's arm-wrestling grip technique and became stronger than his father.

Dorothy Junior: The narrator's daughter, a college student spending a term in London. She is an "especially difficult adversary" and "equally persuasive" as her brother. She won an argument with her father about where to eat dinner by using his guilt as her emotional goal, demonstrating a biting tongue she knows how to restrain. She values comfort and sense above all else. As a three-year-old, she threw a temper tantrum in a bank lobby in Hanover, New Hampshire. She learned from birth that a good persuader manipulates the audience's feelings, not just expresses her own. She knew the persuader bears the burden of emotion. Her temper tantrum showed the danger of over-displaying emotions. She knew Cicero's dictum that good pathetic argument is understated. As a twelve-year-old, she ran ahead during a family hike, disappeared around a turn, and locked herself in the car with the stereo blasting, having taken the car keys. She made her father apologize to get into the car. In high school, she used the "Eddie Haskell Ploy" to bolster her standing with her parents by pretending to sacrifice going to an unsupervised party with alcohol. She is allowed by Dorothy Sr. to sit with friends at a football game. She tells the narrator he should be consistent. She is now a self-directed college junior who aspires to med school. As a child, she expected the narrator to correct her grammar. As a child, she used "silent peroration" (tears welling up) and "Bambi eyes" (long-lashed open stare) to persuade her father for ice cream. She tells the narrator that his losing his temper never worked on her, but his quiet, scary eyes were frightening. She described the narrator's angry outbursts as a "Yosemite Sam thing." She practices bantering with the television, specifically with ads and talking heads. She answered a request to share a toy at nursery school by saying, "You do whatever the hell you want, sweetheart."

The Author/Narrator: A writer and father of George and Dorothy Junior, married to Dorothy. He lives in a tiny village in northern New England and works in a cabin. He dropped out of a career in journalism and publishing, and was formerly an editorial director at the Rodale publishing company. He is passionate about rhetoric, which he discovered through John Quincy Adams, and wrote this book to teach it. He considers himself a "confirmed hermit," "persuasion-resistant," and "advertising-immune." He is the sender of a "You win" message to George. He aims to raise persuasive children. He once carried a coffee mug with "Piss Off" on it, which was not well-received in Greensboro, North Carolina. He hired an entry-level editor who had a bumper sticker claiming a local rock band violated "Your Honor Student." He tried to imitate his brother's method of giving a rose to a woman and calling her "doll," but was told "Go to hell." He sought fashion advice from a salesman named Joe in New Hampshire. He believes that meeting a pointless challenge outweighs values like comfort and sense. He once took over a college alumni magazine, turning a deficit into a profit by increasing advertising revenue, but did not receive raises beyond cost-of-living increases because he acted "businesslike" while academics valued scholarship. He apologized to his twelve-year-old daughter to get into the car after she locked herself in. He made a pact with Dorothy not to treat their kids equally, but to love them equally and deal with each situation separately. He tells George he cannot sit with his friends at a football game, citing Dorothy Jr.'s age as a reason and Machiavelli's idea of inconsistency. His children see him as practically wise in anything that doesn't involve moving parts, but he lacks virtue in their eyes. He described the "dubitatio" technique to his son. He advises nervous speakers to use their butterflies and gradually speak louder. He told his three-year-old daughter her tantrum "isn't pathetic enough" and explained that he is a passionate devotee of classical rhetoric. He believes emotion comes from experience and expectation. He is scheduled to testify before the New Hampshire legislature on broadband Internet access in rural areas, where his dial-up connection is so slow a stamped envelope gets delivered faster than e-mail. He was in a "perverse mood" when George came home in a bad mood and inoculated himself against George's announced anger. His losing his temper never worked on Dorothy Jr., who found it "funny" and called it a "Yosemite Sam thing," but his quiet, scary eyes were frightening to her. Early in his publishing career, he worked for a small magazine that had no fact checkers and mistakenly placed Mount Saint Helens in Oregon in a news piece. He used the backfire technique on his editor, Bill, to confess this mistake. He tries to entertain his unappreciative family with puns. He once lectured on political rhetoric and invented the neologism "eristicrats." He says "You do whatever the hell you want, sweetheart" to his children instead of "Yes" or "All right." He stopped arm-wrestling his son, George, after George learned his grip technique. He is consulting with a publishing company that is bidding for an airline's in-flight magazine. He uses "metastasis" when discussing rhetoric. He once had a rental car scrape in Nice, France.
John Quincy Adams: Taught rhetorical lectures at Harvard College from 1805 to 1809 while a US senator. He was thirty-eight, paunchy, and balding during his first class.
Horace: Attributed as the author of the quote "Concordia discors" (Harmony in discord).
Narrator's Cat: A ten-pound cat that persuades through gesture and tone of voice.
Used Car Salesman: A salesman in Connecticut who seduced the narrator into buying a lemon car.
John Gottman: A research psychologist who, in the eighties and nineties, studied married couples' arguments at the University of Washington's "love lab," announcing his findings in 1994.

Vice President Dick Cheney: Used as an example of "fighting" when he urged U.S. senator Pat Leahy to commit an autoerotic act. His aggressive stance on cruel and inhumane treatment of suspected terrorists gave Bush breathing room on the Iraq war.
George Foreman: Used as an example of making an argument when he tries to sell a grill.
Homer Simpson: Used as an example of making an argument when demonstrating intellectual superiority to dolphins. He is paraphrased for the quote, "what works even more like a drug is drugs."
Mariah Carey: Used as an example of making an argument when singing "We belong together."
Howard Dean: Used as an example of "fighting" when saying Republicans "have never made an honest living."
Yogi Berra: Used as an example of "argument" when saying, "It's not the heat, it's the humility."
John Kerry: A presidential candidate who won debates on "points" against President Bush but lost the election.

President Bush: A presidential candidate whose popularity improved after debates with John Kerry, leading him to win the election. He made a smooth switch in opposing the Department of Homeland Security and then fighting for it when its creation seemed inevitable, without apology or being called a waffler. As president, he used the middle-course tactic by choosing Cheney as a running mate. He is a master of dubitatio and uses the word "misunderestimate." Blue-staters laugh at his "Bushisms," which makes red-staters love him more. The Bush White House used commonplaces like "No Child Left Behind," "Operation Iraqi Freedom," "Clear Skies," "Healthy Forests Initiative," "Culture of Life," and "Marriage Protection." He promoted tort reform by repeatedly referring to "frivolous lawsuits."

Saint Augustine: A one-time rhetoric professor and father of the Christian Church, known for "boffo sermons" that made audiences cry. He is attributed with the quote "Audi partem alteram" (Hear the other side).
Henry Kissinger: Served as Nixon's national security adviser and used a persuasive method of presenting five alternatives, with his preferred one in the middle.

Nixon: President who inevitably chose Kissinger's preferred option. As president, he used the middle-course tactic by choosing Agnew as a running mate. He had a virtue failure due to Watergate violating the American notion of fair play.
Frank Capra: Director of "It's a Wonderful Life," who used "surrogate seduction" to persuade Jimmy Stewart to kiss Donna Reed.
Jimmy Stewart: An actor in "It's a Wonderful Life" who was shy about kissing Donna Reed until Capra changed the scene.
Donna Reed: An actress in "It's a Wonderful Life" who kissed Jimmy Stewart.
Lord Nelson: Attributed with the quote "never mind maneuvers, go straight at 'em."
Aristophanes: A playwright who said that persuasion can make "the lesser side appear the greater." He is attributed with the quote "Even if you persuade me, you won’t persuade me."
Plato: Thought persuasion making "the lesser side appear the greater" was a bad thing. He also believed that attaching values to audiences sounded like relativism.

Cicero: History's greatest orator, who came up with three goals for persuading people: stimulate emotions, change opinion, and get to act. He divorced his wife of thirty years and married a teenager at sixty. He said the most effective rhetoric disguises itself. He claimed humor was one of the most persuasive rhetorical passions. He said decorum that works for one persuader may not work for another, even in front of the same people. He taught that you can't assume a character that strays too far from your own. He listed decorum first among the ethical tactics. He stated that an audience should be receptive, attentive, and well disposed toward the persuader. His dictum is that good pathetic argument is understated. When he spoke, people said, "What a great speech." He listed compassion as a useful emotion. His favorite kind of humor was banter, and he was famously quick with a comeback, but his ridicule led to him being put on a hit list, literally bantering himself to death. He advised Romans not to make jokes about a shocking crime or a pitiful victim.
Marge Simpson: Homer Simpson's wife.
Ned Flanders: A born-again Christian.
Moe: A bartender.
Uncle Randy: The narrator's uncle, who decides to divorce his wife on their thirtieth anniversary to marry a surfing instructor.
Aunt: Uncle Randy's wife, who is being divorced.
Izaak Walton: Author of "The Compleat Angler," attributed with the quote "Thus use your frog, Put your hook through his mouth, and out at his gills...and in so doing use him as though you loved him."
Calvin: A character from the comic strip "Calvin and Hobbes," who uses concession effectively.
Calvin's Dad: A character from the comic strip "Calvin and Hobbes," who tries to teach Calvin to ride a bike.
Narrator's Boss: A former salesman who uses concession to subtly manipulate the narrator.
George H. W. Bush: Used as an example for the quote "I care" in relation to sympathy.
Arlo Guthrie: Used as an example of a "backfire" when he yelled "I wanna kill! Kill!" at draft registration and received a medal.
Kenneth Burke: A modern rhetorician who, in 1950, declared decorum "perhaps the simplest case of persuasion" and offered an inventory of decorous skills.

Narrator's Mother: Was fourteen when "Gone with the Wind" came to the local theater in Wayne, Pennsylvania, and couldn't hear Rhett Butler's profanity due to audience gasps. She had to sit in the balcony with the family's black cook in 1939 in suburban Philadelphia.
Rhett Butler: A character in "Gone with the Wind" whose profanity ("Frankly, my dear, I don’t give a damn") shocked audiences in 1939.

Eminem: A hip-hop artist whose semi-autobiography "8 Mile" features a scene demonstrating decorum in a rap battle in downtown Detroit. He wore a skullcap, baggy clothes, and bling. He is white and won a rap battle against a black opponent by exposing the opponent's prep school background.
Eminem's Adversary: A sullen-looking black guy in a rap battle against Eminem, who attended a prep school.
Narrator's Boss (Greensboro): Told the narrator to switch coffee cups due to his "Piss Off" mug.

Entry-level Editor: Hired by the narrator, she had a bumper sticker advertising a local rock band by claiming it violated "Your Honor Student." She believed it was a freedom of speech issue and refused to remove it, but it was removed for her.

Narrator's Younger Brother (John): Visited the narrator in D.C., bought a rose from a Hare Krishna, and gave it to a woman, calling her "doll," which she appreciated. He is described as irony-free and straight-ahead.
Hare Krishna: Approached the narrator and his brother in Georgetown, D.C., selling scraggly-looking roses.
Dean Martin: Used as a comparison for the narrator's brother calling a woman "doll."

Joe: A salesman at a men's store in New Hampshire, who advised the narrator on dressing decorously for business. He advised looking for expensive shoes but mimicking shirt/tie colors and patterns. He was a fashion consultant for years and counted Captain Kangaroo among his clients.

Bob Keeshan (Captain Kangaroo): A client of Joe, the salesman. He gave the narrator advice on buying a suit: buy it if you'd be willing to wear it every single day for a year without getting tired of it. He had a bad haircut and wore loafer-type shoes.
Comte de Buffon: Attributed with the quote "Style makes the man."
Senator Bob Packwood: An Oregon Republican and effective feminist on Capitol Hill, whose career was wrecked by a decorum disaster in 1992 when word got out he was chasing female staff. He resigned.

Jimmy Carter: Described as a great campaigner, who would wear conservative suits and sweeten them with his broad smile. He was also among the most intellectually endowed presidents but among the least effective due to lack of street smarts. He failed in rhetorical virtue by speaking of a "national malaise," going against American values of optimism.

Isocrates: Attributed with the quote "The argument which is made by a man’s life is of more weight than that which is furnished by words." He is also quoted as saying, "Speech is the leader of all thoughts and actions."
Jesus Christ: Used as an example of "pure kind of virtue."
Julius Caesar: Used as an example of "rhetorical virtue." Shakespeare said his countenance could change his rhetoric "to virtue and to worthiness." He was assassinated.

Janet Jackson: Considered a paragon of virtue by her fans due to pop culture values, but lost virtue when her audience expanded to include those who didn't appreciate exposed nipples on network television.

Bill Clinton: Impeached by the House of Representatives for dalliance with an intern and lying about it. As president, he used the middle-course tactic by choosing Gore as a running mate. He redefined "is" in a "slickest, most lawyerly way."
François Mitterrand: Former French president whose wife and mistress both attended his funeral, which mystified Americans.

Atticus Finch: A Southern lawyer in "To Kill a Mockingbird" who is considered virtuous by viewers but lost rhetorical virtue and his case among 1930s white Southern townsfolk for defending a black man charged with raping a white woman.

Abraham Lincoln: Before becoming president, he used informal language, including racist jokes and the N-word, to appeal to his audience's values, despite his opposition to slavery. This rhetorical virtue made emancipation easier to accept. As a lawyer and two-term former congressman, he was a political nobody in the winter of 1860. He had freakishly big hands, aerodynamic cheeks, and a Western rube’s accent. He used dubitatio at the Cooper Union to lower expectations and convey sincerity, delivering a rational and lawyerly speech that was a smash.

God (Jehovah): In the book of Job, he brags about his power and punishes Job to win a bet with Satan, demonstrating his unquestionable ethos. He bragged about his feats, like inventing the whale, to Job.
Satan: In the book of Job, he bets God that Job would curse him if his life were miserable.
Job: A worshipful man who, after losing his possessions, children, and health due to God's bet with Satan, challenges God but then backs down after God's display of power.
Muhammad Ali: Used as an example of someone whose audience appreciates boastful hyperbole.
John McCain: Rarely talks about his heroism as a prisoner in Vietnam, but others do it for him.

George Washington: Master of the "tactical flaw." During the Revolutionary War, he fumbled with his spectacles and said his eyes had grown dim in service to his country, causing his officers to weep and swear fealty. His officers considered him "God and Caesar rolled up in one."
Eddie Haskell: A fictional character from "Leave It to Beaver" whose ploy of making an inevitable decision against him look like a willing sacrifice is a rhetorical technique.
Narrator's Sister: A ballroom dance instructor.
John Belushi (Bluto): A character from "Animal House" who lacks practical wisdom but has selfless goodwill and shares his brothers' interest for revenge. He eventually becomes a U.S. senator.
Otter: A wiser character from "Animal House" who proposes a plan after Bluto's speech.
Dean Wormer: A character from "Animal House" who expels the fraternity.
Marmalard: A character from "Animal House" whom Bluto wants revenge on.
John Adams: A former US president, intellectually endowed but among the least effective due to lack of street smarts.

Herbert Hoover: A former US president, intellectually endowed but among the least effective due to lack of street smarts. He failed in practical wisdom by following the rules of traditional economics and trying to balance the budget during a depression.
Edison: Used as an example of practical wisdom.
Einstein: Used as an example of lacking practical wisdom.
Han Solo: Used as an example of practical wisdom.
Yoda: Used as an example of lacking practical wisdom.
Captain William Bligh: Commander of the Bounty, who was mediocre when leading by rules but showed practical wisdom by navigating a small boat 3600 nautical miles to safety after the mutiny.
Indiana Jones: Showed practical wisdom by shooting a master swordsman instead of fencing him.
Agnew: Nixon's running mate, chosen for more extreme opinions to make Nixon look moderate.
Gore: Clinton's running mate, chosen for more extreme opinions to make Clinton look moderate.
Machiavelli: Attributed with the idea that inconsistency is a useful leadership tool to keep subjects off guard.
Christoph Martin Wieland: Attributed with the quote "To be not as eloquent would be more eloquent."
Alexander Hamilton: Wrote anonymous letters in *The Federalist* to disguise his "interest" in the proposed new Constitution, even pretending he hadn't attended the Convention.
James Madison: Wrote anonymous letters in *The Federalist* to disguise his "interest" in the proposed new Constitution, even pretending he hadn't attended the Convention.
John Jay: Wrote anonymous letters in *The Federalist* to disguise his "interest" in the proposed new Constitution.
Marie Antoinette: Her enemies planted the quote "Let them eat cake," but her poor ethos made it believable.
Hamlet: Used as an example of lacking practical wisdom, as he follows a ghost's directions.
Quintilian: A chief rhetorician of the early Roman Empire, who explained that a speaker might feign helplessness to appear as an honest man rather than a skilled master of rhetoric.
Harold Holzer: A Lincoln scholar.

Henry Peacham: Attributed with the quote, "The Oratour may lead his hearers which way he list, and draw them to what affection he will: he may make them to be angry, to be pleased, to laugh, to weepe, and lament: to loue, to abhorre, and loath."
Protagoras: A famous Sophist who said that food tastes bitter to an invalid and the opposite to a healthy person, and that "While the doctor makes changes with drugs, the Sophist does it with words."
Stoics: A group of Greeks who believed pain was the secret to all emotions, and that good passions were the absence of pain.
Will: Matt Damon's character in *Good Will Hunting*, who uses first-person storytelling for a joke.
Sean: Robin Williams' character in *Good Will Hunting*, who points out that Will has never been on a plane.
Sam: Danny DeVito's character in *Ruthless People*, the "spandex miniskirt king," who uses a threatening story to his mistress.
Captain White: A well-known ship captain murdered in Massachusetts, whose case was prosecuted by Daniel Webster.
B. T. Barlow: A conservative talk show host in *The Simpsons* who commits a rhetorical error by forgetting pathetic volume control.
Mayor Quimby: A character in *The Simpsons*.
Hitler: Used as an example of a screaming demagogue who almost invariably began a speech quietly and then turned up the volume.
Demosthenes: A fiery Athenian orator; when he spoke, people said, "Let's march!" He spoke more pathetically than Cicero.
Bill (narrator's editor): The narrator's editor at a small magazine early in his publishing career, who accepted the narrator's backfire confession about misplacing Mount Saint Helens.
Dixy Lee Ray: The governor of Washington who was the first reader to point out the narrator's mistake about placing Mount Saint Helens in Oregon.
Artie Fufkin: The publicist in *This Is Spinal Tap* who uses a superb backfire defense when no one shows up for a record signing.

Sigmund Freud: A psychologist who said that making people laugh "relieves anxiety" by releasing impulses in a disciplined manner. He wrote the book *Jokes (Der Witz)*, which is described as hilariously full of unfunny jokes.
Charles Napier: A British general who captured the Indian province of Sind in 1843 and alerted his superiors with a one-word telegram: "PECCAVI" (Latin for "I have sinned").

John Roberts: The Chief Justice who, while working for Ronald Reagan, advised the White House on a Saint Patrick's Day greeting, encouraging them to fact-check the Gaelic phrase "An Teach Ban" (Gaelic for "The White House") because he didn't know if it meant "Free the I.R.A."
Ronald Reagan: President, for whom John Roberts worked.

Laura Bush: The former First Lady who, in 2005, told what ABC News claimed to be "the first public joke ever by a First Lady about the president of the United States engaged in intimate contact with a randy male horse" at the White House Correspondents Dinner, which boosted the president's ratings.
Calvin Coolidge: President, whose ethos is used as a comparison for joke-telling.
Lady Astor: Bantered with Winston Churchill, threatening to flavor his coffee with poison if he were her husband.
Young Man (in Cicero's example): A brash young man in the Forum who used concession to rebut an elder by accepting the insult "pup" and turning it back, saying, "I see a thief."
Elder (in Cicero's example): An elder in the Forum who was rebutted by a young man using concession.
Doc: A character in a joke who gives a man bad news about his health and good news about an affair with a nurse.
Man: A character in a joke who receives bad news about his health and good news about a nurse.
Nurse: A character in a joke who is having an affair with the Doc.
Annie: The narrator's friend, a passionate Democrat from Ohio living on the East Coast, who tried to persuade her former college roommate, Kathy, to vote for Kerry.
Kathy: Annie's former college roommate, who lives in Ohio and plans to vote for Bush because she doesn't want her taxes to go up. She is married to a lawyer.
Professor Harold Hill: A character from *The Music Man* who used the "kids these days" commonplace to sell band instruments.
Mark Twain: Quoted as saying public opinion "is held in reverence" and "settles everything."
Ben Franklin: Famously used anadiplosis in the quote "For want of a shoe the horse was lost, for want of a rider the battle was lost…"
Thomas Jefferson: Kept commonplace books all his life, which reveal public attitudes of his day.
Spartans: An ancient group mentioned as practicing infanticide, who might have objected to "No Child Left Behind."
Britons: Mentioned as potentially not endorsing "Iraqi Freedom" when the empire was at its height.
French: Mentioned as potentially wondering what "protecting marriage" was against.
Aging hippies: A cultural group mentioned in relation to the maxim "It's your thing."
Mr. Burns: Owner of a nuclear power plant in *The Simpsons*, who tries to redefine "meltdown" as "unrequested fission surplus."
Wayne: A character from the movie *Wayne's World*, who redefines "marriage" as "punishment for shoplifting in some countries."
Antony: A character in Shakespeare's *Julius Caesar*, who used definition judo by repeatedly calling Brutus "an honorable man" to make it sound like an accusation.
Brutus: A character in Shakespeare's *Julius Caesar*, who assassinated Caesar and was called "an honorable man" by Antony.
Hillary Clinton: A politician who used the slogan "Make Abortions Safe and Rare."
Trial lawyers: A group from whom the Democratic Party receives money.
Chemists: A specific audience for whom "chemicals" might have a positive connotation.
Loggers: A specific audience for whom "logging" might have a positive connotation.
world_state: Rhetoric is defined as the art of influence, friendship, eloquence, ready wit, and irrefutable logic, and is the art of argument. It is pervasive in daily life, forming a "real-life Matrix" of social interaction, and rhetoric serves as its decoder. The ancients considered it the essential skill of leadership, central to higher education, and it helped create early democracies and influenced historical figures and texts. Though it faded in academia in the 1800s, it is regaining popularity. Key rhetorical concepts include Aristotle's three traits of credible leadership (virtue, disinterest, practical wisdom), the idea that emotion often trumps logic, and the goal of consensus (a shared faith in a choice). Seduction, a form of manipulation, is presented as a powerful tool for achieving consensus. Argument is described as inherent in human nature. Figures of speech, such as chiasmus, antithesis, syncrisis, and dirimens copulatio, are powerful rhetorical tools. Cicero's five-step method for constructing a speech includes invention, arrangement, style, memory, and delivery. New rhetorical concepts and distinctions: - **Argument vs. Fight:** In a fight, each disputant tries to win; in an argument, they try to *win over* an audience. Argument aims for agreement, while fighting aims for domination. Successful couples use arguments to solve problems, while doomed couples use them to attack. "Argument by the stick" (fighting) never persuades, only inspires revenge or retreat. - **Goals of Persuasion (Cicero's Lightbulb):** The three goals for persuading people, in increasing order of difficulty, are to: 1) Stimulate the audience's emotions (easiest, makes them receptive), 2) Change its opinion, and 3) Get it to act (most difficult, requires stronger emotions and convincing the action is "no big deal"). - **The Goal (Argument Tool):** Ask what you want at the end of an argument (change mind, get to do/stop something). Winning means achieving this, regardless of what the opponent thinks. - **Concessio (Concession):** Concede an opponent's point in order to win what you want. It is a powerful Logos tool. - **Prolepsis (Anticipation):** Agreeing in advance to what the other person is likely to say. - **Eristic:** The name for debating that seeks to win points. - **Rhetorical Jujitsu:** Using an opponent's own moves to throw them off balance. - **Goldilocks Technique:** Presenting extreme choices first and last, with the preferred or best-selling option in the middle to make it seem "just right." - **Commitment Ratio:** A measure of whether people actually do what you ask, calculated by dividing "Okays" by follow-throughs. - The most effective rhetoric disguises itself. - Ancient rhetoricians dreaded demagogues (power-mad dictators using rhetorical skills for evil), but believed the cure for the dark side of persuasion is the other side. - **Aristotle's Three Core Issues of Rhetoric:** All issues involving persuasion boil down to three categories, each corresponding to a tense: - **Blame (Past Tense):** Deals with issues of justice and determining whodunit. This is called **forensic rhetoric**, and its purpose is to determine guilt and mete out punishment. - **Values (Present Tense):** Handles praise and condemnation, separating good from bad, distinguishing groups and individuals, and creating tribal identity. This is called **demonstrative rhetoric**, used in communal language like commencement addresses, funeral orations, and sermons. Political rhetoric often uses the present tense to stir up a base, which is considered a poor way to conduct a democracy. - **Choice (Future Tense):** Argues about choices and helps decide how to meet mutual goals. This is called **deliberative rhetoric**. Its chief topic is "the advantageous," focusing on expedience rather than right/wrong or good/bad, and promises a payoff. It is the most pragmatic kind of rhetoric. Deliberative argument relies on public opinion to resolve questions, not a higher power. - **Persuasion vs. Dialectic:** Persuasion aims to talk people into things, while dialectic seeks to discover absolute truth. - **Orphan Annie’s Law:** A successful argument about the future cannot stick to facts, as facts do not exist in the future; it deals with conjecture and choices. - **New Rhetorical Tools and Concepts:** - **Controlling the Tense:** Switching the tense of an argument, especially to the future tense, can resolve conflicts and make decisions. - **Proposing an extreme choice first:** Presenting an undesirable option before the preferred one makes the desired option seem more reasonable. - **Digressions:** Used to change the tone and rhythm of an argument. - **Anticipating audience objections:** Producing objections before the audience can think of them makes listeners more malleable. - **Spotting the inarguable:** Identifying what is permanent, necessary, or undeniably true. Deliberative argument prefers to use beliefs to its advantage rather than debating the inarguable. Moral issues and "eternal truths" are considered inarguable in deliberative rhetoric, while practical concerns are open to debate. - **Argument’s Rule Number One:** Never debate the undebatable; instead, focus on goals. - **Aristotle's Three Most Powerful Tools of Persuasion:** -   **Logos:** Argument by logic. Uses what the audience itself is thinking. -   **Ethos:** Argument by character. Employs the persuader's personality, reputation, and ability to look trustworthy. A sterling reputation is persuasive. -   **Pathos:** Argument by emotion. Appeals to the heart and is useful for getting people to act. -   **Hypophora:** A figure of speech that asks a rhetorical question and then immediately answers it, used to anticipate audience skepticism. -   **Sympathy:** A pathetic tactic that involves sharing your listeners' mood, registering concern for their emotions, and then changing the mood to suit your argument. -   **Oversympathizing:** A technique that makes someone's mood seem ridiculous without actually ridiculing it. -   **Backfire:** A technique where an attempt to oversympathize or ridicule backfires. -   **Decorum:** The concession side of ethos. - **Decorum:** The art of fitting in; matching the audience’s expectations for a leader’s tone, appearance, and manners. It originally meant "fit" or "suitable" in Latin. It tells the audience, "Do as I say *and* as I do." It means acting the way your audience *expects* you to act, not necessarily like your audience. It is considered "perhaps the simplest case of persuasion." It is a critical persuasive tool. Indecorous and persuasive are mutually exclusive. It is the concession side of ethos. It is the art of the appropriate. It is an aspect of sympathy. It is the first ethical tactic listed by Cicero. - **Ethos (original Greek meaning):** Originally meant "habitat"—the environment animals and people live in. It relates to a person's ability to fit in with a group's expectations. - **Aporia:** A rhetorical device where one wonders openly or admits inability to fathom a reason, causing the audience to unconsciously start reasoning for them. - **Dialysis:** A "this-not-that" figure of speech, e.g., "Don't buy the shoes. Buy the colors." - **Argument's Civic Virtue:** Argument can result in peace, love, freedom, and mastery of one's fellow beings. - **Persuasion vs. Being True to Yourself:** Persuasion depends on being true to your audience, not necessarily true to yourself. - **Decorum in Politics:** More complex than in business because the personal is political. - **Decorum in the Senate:** Crucial for maintaining a high state of decorum to prevent political squabbles or civil war. - **Dress Decorum:** Dress the way the average audience member dresses, or slightly above your rank, but not too far above. Don't let clothes make a statement unless the audience agrees with it. - **PowerPoint Presentation Decorum:** Adapting language, posture, and formality for different audiences (department head, VP, COO). - **Writing Decorum:** Checking emails and memos for decorum to meet audience expectations. - **Ethos (expanded):** Requires the audience to trust the persuader's judgment and essential goodness, believing they know the right thing to do and will not use them for nefarious purposes. Aristotle's three essential qualities of persuasive ethos are: **Virtue** (the audience believes you share their values), **Practical wisdom** (you appear to know the right thing to do), and **Selflessness/Disinterest** (the audience's interest seems to be your sole concern). Persuasive virtue does not require purity of soul or universal goodness; it means being seen to have the audience's "right" values. Values are a tool of ethos in deliberative argument and change from audience to audience. What seems ethical to one person can hurt another's ethos. To build ethos, one must determine and appear to live up to the audience's values, avoiding judgment of those one wishes to persuade. Rhetoric is an agnostic art, requiring adaptation to audience values, which may include honor, faith, steadfastness, money, or possessions. - **The Perfect Audience:** Is receptive (sitting still), attentive (willing to listen closely), and well disposed toward the persuader (liking and trusting them). - **Litotes:** Understates a point ironically, making for a more sophisticated kind of speech. - **Virtus:** The Roman meaning of "virtue," which meant "manliness"—good sportsmanship, respect for values, and all-around nobility. - **Persuasion Alert (Interrupting yourself):** Addressing a different audience (even a virtual one) to keep the original audience engaged. - **Persuasion Alert (Relativism):** The point of rhetoric is to argue effectively, not to transform a person into a better or worse one, even if attaching values to audiences sounds like relativism. - **Bragging:** A rhetorical tool to show how great one is, effective only if the audience appreciates boastful hyperbole. - **Character Reference:** Getting others to brag for you, which Aristotle considered more effective than self-bragging. - **Tactical Flaw:** Revealing a weakness that wins sympathy or demonstrates a sacrifice made for the audience. - **Opinion Switch:** Heartily supporting the opposing side when an argument is doomed to go against you, ideally by showing new information or logic made the switch inevitable. - **The Eddie Haskell Ploy:** Making an inevitable decision against you look like a willing sacrifice on your part. - **Candidus:** Latin for "white," the root of "candidates" (who wore white togas to symbolize virtue) and "candy." "Candid" also used to mean "openminded." - **Rhetoric's purpose (expanded):** It is as much about awareness and attitude as it is about technique, aiming to build an instinct for persuasion rather than just a set of tools. - **Four ways to pump up rhetorical virtue:** Get a witness to brag for you, reveal a tactical flaw, switch sides when the powers that be do, or use the Eddie Haskell Ploy (throwing support behind the inevitable). - **Practical Wisdom (Phronesis):** The second major element of ethos. It is the appearance of knowing what to do, the audience thinking you know how to solve the problem at hand. It entails common sense that can get things done, an instinct for making the right decision on every occasion, not just sticking to rules or universal truths. It is more Edison than Einstein, more Han Solo than Yoda. It is flexibly wise leadership. - **Three tools to get an audience to trust your decision (related to practical wisdom):** 1) **Show off your experience:** Brag about experiences, not yourself. Experience usually trumps book learning in an argument. 2) **Bend the rules:** If the rules don't apply, don't apply them, unless ignoring them violates the audience’s values. 3) **Seem to take the middle course:** Make the audience think your adversary’s position is an extreme one, and propose a decision that lies midway between extremes. - **Three parts of a proposal:** Payoffs (benefits), doability (ease of doing), and superiority (how it beats other options). These do not necessarily need to be in this order. - The ancient Greeks had far more respect for moderation than modern culture. - Humans in every era instinctively prefer a decision that lies midway between extremes. - Inconsistency is a useful leadership tool, as it keeps the ruler’s subjects off guard (Machiavelli). - Girls mature more quickly than boys. - Sharing an audience's values (virtue) is not sufficient; they also have to believe you know the right thing to do (practical wisdom). - **Disinterested Goodwill:** Aristotle's third ethos asset, combining selflessness and likability, meaning being free of any special interest. Historically, a reputation for selflessness determined political election, with leaders disguising their "interest" (e.g., *The Federalist* authors) or claiming impoverished childhoods. "Libertas" originally meant both freedom and frankness, allowing "disinterested" people to speak freely. - **The Reluctant Conclusion:** An argument tool where one acts as though compelled to reach a conclusion despite personal desires, making it sound like the opinion was reached only after confronting overwhelming evidence. - **Personal Sacrifice:** An argument tool where one acts as if the choice advocated hurts them personally, or helps the audience more than oneself. - **Dubitatio:** An argument tool where one feigns helplessness or doubt about what to say, making them appear honest and sincere rather than a skilled rhetorician. This technique can lower expectations and cause opponents to "misunderestimate" you. - For nervous speakers, a tactical flaw is to use butterflies and gradually speak louder to sound like confidence is gained from the speech's content. - Ancient Greek audiences trusted plain-spoken leaders more than skilled ones, preferring "pure" Greek over "Asian" (fancy) talk. - **The Aquinas Maneuver:** A rhetorical strategy focused on controlling the mood. - **Pathos (expanded):** Means more than just "feelings"; also physical sensations (what a person feels or suffers). Done properly, it affects an audience’s judgment, as the limbic system tends to overpower the more rational parts of the brain. Reality looks different under different emotions. It comes from experience and expectation (what the audience believes has happened or will happen). The more vividly an experience is given, the greater the emotion aroused. It works best at the end of an argument and poorly at the beginning. It can work subtly in small groups. It makes the difference between agreement and commitment. - **Pathology:** The medical term for the study of diseases, related to pathos. - **Sophists:** Ancient rhetoricians who said pathos affects an audience’s judgment. - **Emotions (Aristotle's view):** Come from belief about what we value, know, and expect. Can be modified through beliefs. Some emotions (sorrow, shame, humility) can prevent action altogether, making people introspective. Other emotions (joy, love, esteem, compassion) work better. Tribal instincts are useful emotions for action, exploiting insecurities about group standing/belonging. - **Pain:** Considered the secret to all emotions by the Stoics. - **Disbelief:** Can prevent fear. - **Humor:** Ranks highest in persuasiveness, improves ethos, calms people down, and makes the persuader appear to stand above petty squabbles. However, it is awful at motivating action. - **Fear:** Aristotle called its use a fallacy ("argument by the stick") because it compels people to act, precluding choice. - **Anger:** Gets the fastest action, but angry people tend not to think far ahead; thus, it is not the best emotion for deliberative argument (decisions about the future). It is useful for courtroom rhetoric. It often arises from frustrated desire or a sense of belittlement. Young people, the poor, and the sick rouse to anger more easily. - **Patriotism:** Does a better job of looking into the future than anger. It is rhetorical group loyalty (for a country, high school, team, or company), not idealism. It is an essentially competitive emotion, often triggered by a rival group's success or when one's group is under threat. - **Emulation:** An emotional response to a role model, stemming from an atavistic need to belong. For it to work, the persuader needs to start with a model the audience already admires. - **Identification:** Action requires identification (with the persuader and the action they promote). - **Rhetorical Tools/Concepts (New or Expanded):** - **Storytelling:** The best way to change an audience’s mood. Make it directly involve you or your audience. A well-told narrative gives the audience a virtual experience, especially if it calls on their own past experiences and is told in the first person. The more vivid the story, the more it seems like a real experience, creating vicarious experience and expectation. - **Emotional Volume Control:** Don’t visibly exaggerate your emotions; let your audience do that for you. Underplaying emotions, in an apparent struggle to contain oneself, can be more effective. Demagogues often begin quietly and gradually increase volume. - **Simple Speech:** Don’t use fancy language when emotional; ornate speech belongs to ethos and logos, while plain speaking is more pathetic. - **Peroration:** The concluding part of a speech, an apt time for pathos. - **The Pathetic Ending:** Emotion works best at the end of an argument. - **The Belittlement Charge:** Show your opponent dissing your audience’s desires. It is the easiest way to stimulate anger. - **Patriotism (as a tool):** Rouse your audience’s group feelings by showing a rival group’s success. - **Emulation (as a tool):** Provide only the kind of role model your audience already admires. - **Unannounced Emotion:** Don’t advertise a mood; invoke it. Tipping off an audience in advance makes them resist the emotion. - **Neurological research:** Confirmed Sophists' theory that pathos affects judgment; the limbic system (seat of emotions) tends to overpower the more rational parts of the brain. - **Ironic time:** The modern era is more ironic, requiring speakers to distance themselves from overly pathetic appeals. - **Adman's presentation technique:** Lowering one's voice gradually to make people lean in, then ending with an emotional crescendo. - **Writing classes dictum:** "Show, don't tell" for emotions. - **Inoculation (against emotion):** Giving advance warning of an emotion can make an audience resist it. - **Cicero vs. Demosthenes:** Cicero's speeches elicited "What a great speech," while Demosthenes's speeches prompted "Let's march!" This illustrates that emotion makes the difference between agreement and commitment. - **New Rhetorical Tools and Concepts:** *   **The Passive Voice:** A rhetorical device used to calm passions by disembodying the speaker and removing actors, making events seem to happen on their own. It encourages passivity and is a pathos trick. It can be used to describe wrongdoing by others without assigning blame directly, but should not be used when the speaker is the culprit. *   **Backfire (expanded):** A technique to inspire sympathy by exaggerating the emotions the audience feels through a *mea culpa* routine. It works best one-on-one with someone known and liked, and can strengthen relationships after a screwup. It is risky as the audience might comply with an exaggerated request. *   **Humor (expanded):** The best calming device for most emotions, except anger. It relieves anxiety by releasing impulses in a disciplined manner. *   **Urbane humor:** Relies on wordplay and depends on an educated audience. It is the only kind of humor one can teach oneself. *   **Wit:** Drier than urbanity, mildly amusing, and plays off the situation rather than wordplay. *   **Facetious humor:** Covers most jokes, its sole purpose is to make people laugh. Rhetoricians generally frown upon it, but it can defuse a touchy argument through distraction. *   **Banter:** A form of attack and defense consisting of clever insults and snappy comebacks. It works best in rhetorical defense, often using concession to throw an opponent's argument back at them. Cicero's favorite kind of humor, but it led to his death. *   **Banter with concession:** A technique where one accepts an adversary's statement at face value, then follows its logic to a ridiculous conclusion or throws it back with a twist. *   **Emotional Volume Control (expanded):** Demagogues often begin speeches quietly and gradually increase volume. *   **Inoculation (against emotion):** Giving advance warning of an emotion can make an audience resist it. - **The Advantageous:** Base your argument on what’s good for the audience, not for you. It is an outcome that gives the audience what it values. It is the über-topic of deliberative argument, dealing with choices and the future, and talks about what is best for the audience. - Aristotle maintained that the person most affected by a decision makes the best judge of it (e.g., the diner is more qualified to judge a dish than the chef). - The burden of proof in an argument is on the persuader. - To prove a point, start with something your audience believes or wants. - Aristotle was a great believer in corporal punishment and said a slave’s testimony was invalid except under torture. - In politics, the advantageous usually wins in the long run, as statecraft is a selfish art. When arguing for military action, show how your country would benefit. - **Babbling:** Aristotle's term for an arguer’s tendency to repeat themselves over and over, which reveals the bedrock of the audience’s opinion. An unpersuadable audience tends to repeat the same rationale. - **The Commonplace:** A viewpoint your audience holds in common; a short-form expression of common sense or public opinion. It can range from a political belief to a practical matter. Commonplaces represent beliefs or rules of thumb, not facts. People identify with their groups through commonplaces, which also determine self-identity. It is the starting point of an argument. - **Topic:** The word comes from the Greek *topos*, meaning "place," and offers points of view. - Commonplaces work like neural shortcuts, similar to how the brain recognizes a familiar face. - Commonplaces are used by filmmakers as shorthand to express character without unnecessary dialogue or explication (e.g., a two-day beard and whiskey connote an alcoholic; a hero wincing when a woman dabs him with antiseptic shows his sensitive side). - **Rhetorical labeling:** The application of commonplaces to legislation, bumper stickers, and talk radio. - Commonplaces help define a culture and identity (e.g., American commonplaces like freedom, clear skies, healthy forests, life, marriage). - Every commonplace has a potential counter-commonplace (e.g., "Pro Life" vs. "Pro Choice," "Culture of Life" vs. "Culture of Freedom"). - "Life" has more pathetic value than "choice" in the antiabortion movement. - Commonplaces are powerful weapons and should not be aimed at one's own foot. - Listening for commonplaces can reveal audience values: "journey" (adventure/growth), "kids these days" (dislikes rap music), "It's not PC to say this, but…" (low regard for cultural nuance). - **The Rejection:** An audience will often say no in the form of a commonplace, which then becomes the new starting ground for the argument, provided the argument can continue. - **Anadiplosis:** A figure of speech that builds one thought on top of another by taking the last word of a clause and using it to begin the next clause (e.g., "For want of a shoe the horse was lost, for want of a rider the battle was lost…"). It turns an argument into an "unstoppable juggernaut of logic." - When researching a prospective employer, Google the CEO for catchwords/commonplaces to understand the company's lingo and tone. - **Commonplace books:** Collections of practical wisdom kept by students since the Renaissance, used in arguments. Thomas Jefferson kept them. - Commonplaces are things everybody knows; they become clichés when repeated until people are sick of them. - Tracking commonplaces helps follow trends in values and shifts in public opinion. Opinion polls can track maxims. - Examples of maxims (commonplaces): "Don't switch horses in midstream" (after 9/11), "Americans have a right to privacy in their own home," "We're at war," "It's your thing. Do what you want to do. I can't tell you who to sock it to" (a few decades ago), "It's about values" (early 1990s). - When commonplaces clash, arguments begin. - Mark Twain said public opinion "is held in reverence" and "settles everything," with some thinking it is the "Voice of God." - The original definition of "audience" meant a "hearing" before a king or nobleman; the first audience was a judge. - In deliberative argument, the audience's own beliefs, values, and naked self-interest determine the outcome, not statute books. - To persuade, offer the "advantageous," which is the promise that your choice will give the judges what they value. - Logos makes the audience think that your own opinion is a very small step from their commonplace. - **The Commonplace Label:** Apply a commonplace to an idea, a proposal, or a piece of legislation; anyone who opposes it will risk seeming like an outsider. - **Definition:** A persuasive strategy for getting a favorable grip on an argument, used to define terms and issues in one's favor, and can win an argument without facts. - **Stance (Status Theory):** A fallback strategy for argument: fact, definition, quality, relevance. If facts don't work, redefine terms; if that fails, argue less importance (quality); if that fails, claim irrelevance. This order is descending in preference. - **Redefinition:** A rhetorical tool to not automatically accept an opponent's meaning of a word, but to redefine it in one's favor, making it sound like agreement while undermining the argument. - **Connotation:** The unconscious thoughts that a term sparks in people's minds. - **Denotation:** The literal meaning of a word. - **Labeling:** The rhetorical practice of attaching a pejorative term to a person or concept. - **Definition Jujitsu:** A rhetorical tool to accept an opponent's term and its connotation, then defend it as a positive thing. - **Periphrasis (Circumlocution):** A figure of speech that swaps a description for a name, useful for labeling a person or issue. - **Definition Judo:** A rhetorical tool to use contrasting terms that make opponents look bad. - **Metastasis:** A manipulative figure of speech that skips over an awkward subject. - **Commonplace words:** Key words that form commonplaces and carry emotional weight with an audience. - **Issue:** What an argument is about; every issue has two descriptions. - **Framing:** The same as defining an issue; involves finding a persuadable audience's commonplaces, defining the issue in the broadest context, and then dealing with the specific problem in the future tense. - **Broad context vs. narrow context:** A broad context generally trumps a narrow one in political situations, including office politics. - In politics, "pro" usually beats "con." - **Term changing:** A technique to not accept the terms an opponent uses, but to insert one's own. - South Dakota passed a "draconian law" banning all abortions regardless of the mother's health or circumstances, which was considered a rhetorical and political mistake.
initial_premise: The narrator, a writer and proponent of rhetoric, engages in a rhetorical exchange with his son, George, where the narrator tells George, "You win," while internally believing he himself won. This interaction is presented as an example of unresisted persuasion, specifically George switching the argument from blame (past tense) to choice (future tense). A message stating "You win" is also addressed to Dorothy (the narrator's wife). The narrator's daughter, Dorothy Junior, also wins an argument with her father about dinner, using guilt as her emotional goal. The narrator also recounts an argument with his seven-year-old son, George, about wearing shorts in winter, where George instinctively used rhetorical tools (character, logic, emotion) to win, leading the narrator to concede. The narrator also describes an incident where his twelve-year-old daughter, Dorothy Junior, locked herself in the car with the keys, forcing him to apologize to gain entry, demonstrating his lack of persuasive virtue in her eyes. Dorothy Junior also successfully uses the "Eddie Haskell Ploy" in high school to bolster her standing with her parents by feigning a sacrifice. The narrator's interaction with his three-year-old daughter, Dorothy Junior, during a temper tantrum in a bank lobby, where he told her her argument "isn't pathetic enough," highlights his early and consistent application of rhetorical principles in parenting. The narrator's family values an occasional, skillfully uttered obscenity as a commonplace, with the narrator saying "You do whatever the hell you want, sweetheart" to his children, a phrase Dorothy Junior later used at nursery school. The narrator stopped arm-wrestling his son, George, after George learned his grip technique, which the narrator describes as a persuasive strategy of definition.
open_questions: What did Dorothy (the narrator's wife) win, and what was the context of her victory?
Is the "You win" message to Dorothy (the narrator's wife) related to the narrator's rhetorical experiment or a separate event?
